fields.bodyText: Video showing Spanish riot police striking demonstrators in Tarragona today (see 6.55pm) With Madrid looking calmer again after the earlier clashes (see 9.26pm post) I'm going to suspend live-blogging operations for the evening. Thanks to all for reading, commenting, sharing photos and offering help and info over Twitter and by email. It's appreciated. Remember, El Pais is streaming the events in Madrid. Here's the scene a few minutes ago: I'll be back in the morning for another day's action - including all the fallout from today's pan-European protests. Until then, goodnight! Sara Firth of Russia Today has tweeted another photo from Madrid: This video on Bambuser shows the protests that took place in Barcelona this evening. At 11 minutes in, you can see riot police officers firing weapons at the crowd -- the rubber bullets that were pictured earlier this evening? (see 7.50pm) Madrid's riot police have also tangled with demonstrators tonight. Sara Firth of Russia Today is at the scene, and reports: This photo of Madrid's Columbus Square shows the full extent of the crowds who gathered for tonight's anti-austerity rally. The El Pais live feed from Madrid just showed a fire engine driving slowly through a crowd of demonstrators, many of whom applauded it. Heartening, after such a day Just to add to the sense of alarm tonight, the Dow Jones industrial average just slid 184 points to close at 12571, down nearly 1.5%. Today's Israeli air strike in Gaza, the protests in Europe, and the looming US fiscal cliff are all being blamed. Emergency vehicles in Madrid are now racing to deal with a fire: Meanwhile, speech are still taking place in the Spanish capital (you can hear occasional applause on the El Pais live feed, and then enthusiastic cheering) Looking around, I think the best way to track the events in Madrid this evening is thls live TV feed on the El Pais website Here's a screengrab: The photo above shows the anger in Madrid tonight. And the link in the tweet below shows the scale of the protests (sorry, you'll have to click on the link) Here's AP's take on today's events: Hundreds of thousands of Europe's beleaguered citizens went on strike or snarled the streets of several capitals Wednesday, at times clashing with riot police, as they demanded that governments stop cutting benefits and create more jobs. Workers with jobs and without spoke of a "social emergency" crippling the world's largest economic bloc, a union of 27 nations and half a billion people. The protests were met with tear gas in Italy and Spain, but were largely limited to the countries hardest hit by the austerity measures designed to bring government spending into line with revenues. Wealthier nations like Germany, the Netherlands and Denmark saw only small, sedate demonstrations. Another photo from Madrid shows how the centre of the Spanish capital is jam-packed with protesters tonight. Worth remembering that the protests in Spain actually began late last night. Freelance journalist Dan Hancox has written about how around 4,000 union activists hit the streets before midnight: Everyone piled up on flags, stickers, fire-crackers, horns, whistles and flyers, and at 11.45pm, set off to shut down the capital of Spain. Dan's blog also has a great selection of photos from the early hours of the Spanish protests, before dawn broke. Our correspondents across Europe report this evening: Hundreds of thousands of Europeans have mounted one of the biggest coordinated anti-austerity protests across the continent on Wednesday, marching against German-orchestrated cuts as the eurozone is poised to move back into recession. Millions took part in Europe-wide strikes, and in city after city along the continent's debt-encrusted Mediterranean rim, thousands marched and scores were arrested after clashes with police. There were banners declaring "Austerity kills," Occupy masks, flares, improvised loudspeakers and cancelled flights. But there was also a violent, even desperate edge to the demonstrations, particularly in Madrid and several Italian cities. In the Spanish capital, police fired rubber bullets to subdue the crowd; in Pisa, protesters occupied the Leaning Tower, and in Sicily cars were burned. "There is a social emergency in the south," said Bernadette Ségol, the secretary general of the European Trade Union Confederation. "All recognise that the policies carried out now are unfair and not working." The full story is here. Photos have emerged tonight showing a rubber bullet (or bullets) that were fired in Barcelona today: That, along with the disturbing video footage of protesters being struck by riot police in Tarragona (see 6.55pm), is likely to further fuel anger in Spain against the methods that are being used against those who choose to demonstrate. Christopher Pissarides, professor at the London School of Economics, has argued this evening that Europe's governments blundered by imposing fiscal consolidation too quickly, and not holding back until they had addressed the flaws in the eurozone. Appearing on Sky News tonight, Pissarides also said Europe's banks were inflaming the situation by reining in their lending: Huge numbers of people are taking part in protests in Madrid this evening, packing the streets of the capital as European citizens continue to mark the November 14 protests. Photos from the city suggest that the number of demonstrators runs into the hundreds of thousands, with people carrying banners with slogans such as "Justice": Just found some TV footage of the moment riot police in Lisbon moved in to disperse protests in the city centre: Reuters is reporting that a small group of protesters threw rocks and stones at riot police protecting the parliament building in Lisbon tonight - which may explain why they began clearing people away (see 6.25pm). A video has emerged which shows three Spanish riot police lashing out at demonstrators in the city of Tarragona today: The brief clip does not show what led up to the incident, but it begins with one officer chasing a man down the street waving a baton, and striking another person* who falls to the floor clutching their head, and is then hit by a second officer (possibly twice) Another member of the public then remonstrates with the police, and is pushed back before then being struck three times by two officers. The nasty scene is played out to a background of police sirens. * - Update: the individual who is attacked while lying on the ground appears to actually be a boy. A photo of a child who was left bleeding following a police charge was circulating today: (Hat-tip to the Daily Telegraph for making the connection) In London tonight, a union-organised rally is taking place at the EC's offices in Westminster, to show support for those suffering from austerity in Europe. These tweets show more details (with thanks to @FBeyondBorders) Live TV footage from Lisbon in the last few minutes showed that the protests there have now turned violent – with riot police driving people along the streets. Here's a screengrab from Sky News: Our foreign correspondents from across Europe have written about the protests on their patch today, and the reasons why citizens have gone on strike or taken to the streets today: European strikes: who is protesting and why? Protests took place in 39 Portuguese cities today. And despite public anger over the country's austerity programme, they remained pretty peaceful. Union officials estimate that at least 50% of public sector workers took part in today's general strike. The most dramatic scenes were in Lisbon where people marched on the parliament building, where MPs were debating the 2013 budget. That legislation includes further austerity measure, including income tax hikes, and increases in sales tax. Here's a selection of photos from Portugal: There have been serious clashes between demonstrators and riot police in several Italian cities. Thousands of protesters have taken to the streets of Italy today, frequently clashing with with police who have made multiple arrests, reports our man in Rome, Tom Kington. There appear to have been running battles at one stage between the two sides in Turin, Riot police also went toe-to-toe (or baton to head?) in Rome and Milan. Here are some pictures: Tom Kington has full details: Students were in the front line in noisy and often violent anti-austerity marches. In Naples and Brescia, protesters occupied rail tracks, in Genoa the entrance to the ferry port was blocked. In Turin a police officer was hit with a baseball bat. Trento, Trieste and Palermo also saw protests, as did Padua where two police men were injured in clashes, while 10,000 marched in Bologna. In Pisa, protesters hung banners from the top of the Leaning Tower. Clashes occured in Milan, while in Venice protesters draped banners in a bank reading “You are making money out of our debts”. Banking in a nutshell?... Another sign of violence today: this photo from Valencia appears to show a police officer kicking a woman during today's protests. It's worth noting that the man who represented Greece's creditors in this year's bond restructuring (in which €107bn was wiped off its debt pile), has criticised Europe's austerity drive today Charles Dallara, head of the Institute of International Finance, delivered a scathing attack on the policies of austerity in Athens. Our own Helena Smith was there, and reports: “Europe and Greece need to steer a new course to find a better balance between austerity and growth, between short-term fiscal discipline and long-term expansions of output and employment opportunities,” Dallara said in a speech outlining the strategy that he argued was required for Greece and Europe to emerge from the crisis. “A return to real, sustainable economic growth can be the only genuine solution to Europe’s crisis,” he told the Hellenic Bank Association. “It is time to recognize that austerity alone condemns not just Greece but the whole of Europe to the probability of a painful and protracted era of little or no economic growth. This would be a tragedy not just for Greece and for Europe, but for the world.” In remarks after the speech, the American described as “excessive” the pace of fiscal adjustment “It has been excessive and contribute to this dramatic contraction of the economy,” he told me. We don’t need to throw out the [IMF-EU fiscal consolidation] programme altogether and there are definitely good things in it but we need urgently to change course.” So it's not just Europe's unions who are calling for a new approach... This two photos from Madrid show that some businesses preferred to carry on than take part in today's general strike " People in Austria have also taken part in today's protests, even though the country has the lowest unemployment rate in the eurozone and has not (yet) felt the impact of austerity directly. Amela Muratovic reports that around 350 people were dancing sirtaki (a Greek jig) in the heart of Vienna beneath St Stephen's cathedral. Amela explains: It was a message of support and solidarity with the Greek people, but also with other people on Europe who are suffering from austerity measures. "We are all Greek" was the title of this activity. And here's a second picture: The Guardian Picture Desk have created a gallery of the best photos from today's protests, from press snappers across Europe: Anti-austerity strikes and protests across Europe As a reminder -- we're also collecting readers' photos here. This graph, via City firm M&G, shows how unemployment in Spain and Greece have soared since the crisis began, helping to fuel the public anger that lead to today's strike. M&G's Richard Woolnough points out that over the last 10 years the sick and healthy economies of Europe have alternated: the strong core and the weak periphery were the weak core and the booming periphery in the middle of the last decade. and says the speed of the switch is due to the inflexibility of the single currency. Woolnough also questions whether today should really be called a 'day of action': The day of action means in reality a day of inaction, as the active protesting on the streets is outweighed by the inactive sectors such as transportation hit by the strike. Not that there was much inactivity in Madrid or Milan today... Cándido Méndez, secretary-general of Spain’s UGT union, has thanked those who took part in today's general strike, saying We are deeply grateful to the workers, who are in a very difficult situation with unemployment at almost six million That's via the FT, which also reports a "sense of trepidation on the streets" of Madrid ahead of demonstrations planned for this evening. Further proof that the eurozone crisis is causing serious damage to society - malaria is making a comeback in Greece. The Wall Street Journal has more. This video clip shows a group of people (mainly students, I think) occupying Naples central railway station today. That's via La Repubblica, which has other video clips on its site too. Opposition members of the Spanish parliament held up posters in support of the pan-European strike action today. Alfredo Perez Rubalcaba, leader of the opposition PSOE party, warned that many people will "get left behind" unless the Madrid government changes its economic policy. In Brussels, people gathered outside the offices of the European Commission this morning for a demonstration organised by the country's trade unions. People at the scene report that protesters chanted "We want another Europe!" for around an hour, taking the message from southern Europe to within earshot of European officials. Here are some photos from Brussels today: From Madrid, Jaime Giménez sends a photo showing riot police vans lined up in the Spanish capital and armed (he says) with dedicated riot guns for firing rubber ammunition. As mentioned at 1.57pm, Reuters has reported that rubber bullets were fired at protesters in Madrid earlier today (not clear if anyone was hit). In Athens, Helena Smith reports that demonstrators have spent the last hour amassed in front of the parliament in Syntagma square She says the turnout was small, due to Greeks being "exhausted and disoriented" by relentless waves of punitive measures. But what was striking was the talk of the country's imminent social implosion. Helena writes: Across the board I heard people say that they had been able to survive, so far, because of hand-outs from their parents or family support. "But when that dries up, and it will with these latest measures, there will be no reason not to descend en masse onto the streets," said Kostas Kapetanakis, a young sociologist holding a banner demanding free education, health and welfare system. "There will be a revolt because we will have absolutely nothing to lose." Nikos Bokaris, the mild-mannered president of the national foresters' association who was standing with other civil servants outside the parlaiment, feared Greece was being pushed towards a massive explosion. "Civil servants feel they have been very unfairly singled out," he told me. "I am very afraid that the country is heading for a massive social upheaval with huge consequences for public safety and order. All it will take is a spark." The number of people arrested in Spain during today's protests has now risen to 81. Reuters is reporting that riot police fired rubber bullets at protesters in Madrid, where some of the largest protests have taken place. In Rome, American journalist Barbie Latza Nadeau reports that the Italian capital is "paralysed" as several anti-austerity demonstrations merge into a single mass. The protests in Athens today (see 10.54am for details) appear to have passed off peacefully. Pictures from the scene show that marchers carried banners criticising European austerity (just days after the Greek parliament approved billions of euros of new cuts), while some people performed a puppet show in which Europe was assailed from all sides: Today's strike action has been criticised by a European employers organisation, which fears the walkout will damage Europe's already-weak economy and deter potential foreign investors. Philippe de Buck , the chief of Eurobusiness – the Brussels-based EU employers' federation – said: If you start striking at national level and in companies you only will harm the economy, and it is not the right thing to do today... It costs billions [of euros]. I can't find any authoritative estimates for the cost of today's action. But analysts have reckoned that major disruption to the UK economy (through bad weather or a bank holiday) costs upwards of £1bn -- so it's clear that the general strikes in Spain and Portugal, plus walkouts in Italy and Greece, will have a significant cost. Manufacturers may be able to recover the lost hours, but service companies may not (commuters in Madrid won't buy twice as many coffees, newspapers or sandwiches tomorrow, for example). Many thanks to everyone who's shared photos from today's protests - our Readers' Gallery has a lot of fine pictures already: To share yours, just click here. More photos of the protests in Madrid have arrived, showing riot police apprehending some demonstrators: The number of arrests in Spain still stands at 62. Protesters in Madrid have also plastered shop windows with anti-government stickers, and Reuters reports that some cash machines have been jammed with glue (we flagged up at 10.11am that they had been vandalised) New economic data released this morning shows that austerity continues to have a dreadful impact on southern Europe. Portugal's economy shrank by 0.8% in the third quarter of the year, more than economists expected. This means the country's GDP is 3.4% lower than a year ago, when it was in the early stages of an 'adjustment programme' having accepted a €78bn bailout. Unemployment in Portugal has also hit a record high today of 15.8% for the last quarter. Separate data showed that Greece's economy is faring even worse - GDP has contracted by 7.2% over the last year. Some readers are asking what is the alternative to Europe's current economic path. So here's what the European Trades Union Convention (which called today's co-ordinated strike) has proposed instead of austerity-driven cuts and tax rises. • Economic governance at the service of sustainable growth and quality jobs, • Economic and social justice through redistribution policies, taxation and social protection, • Employment guarantees for young people, • An ambitious European industrial policy steered towards a green, low-carbon economy and forward-looking sectors with employment opportunities and growth, • A more intense fight against social and wage dumping, • Pooling of debt through Euro-bonds, • Effective implementation of a financial transaction tax to tackle speculation and enable investment policies, • Harmonisation of the tax base with a minimum rate for companies across Europe, • A determined effort to fight tax evasion and fraud, • Respect for collective bargaining and social dialogue, • Respect for fundamental social and trade union rights. Some of you have been sharing your pictures from protests and strikes across Europe. For users posting images to Instagram, you can share your photo with us and be added to our gallery here by posting a picture with the tag #14N (make sure you have 'add your photo to map' turned on). On Twitter you can send us a picture direct to @Guardian with the tag #14N and we'll add you to today's gallery of photos And if you're in Greece we have a Flickr group set up here [http://www.flickr.com/groups/greek-crisis/] where you can upload a photo. You can also email hannah.waldram@guardian.co.uk direct or leave a comment below. Thanks! This video clip shows the early morning protest in Spain, where union leaders claimed that the European commission was imposing austerity on Spaniards "on the orders of Berlin". Here's a couple more photos from the marches in Italy this morning: This video clip appears to show a clash between demonstrators and riot police this morning in Milan. It begins with a large group of people carrying banners and placards, who march up to a line of riot police. What appear to be petrol bombs (or possibly flares) are thrown at the officers, at which point they charge the students (hitting several with their batons). The protesters then regroup and march towards the police again (using their placards as a shield wall, rather like a phalanx), and a second clash takes place. The video comes from Maurizio Sartori - you can see more of his clips here. Some of the most violent scenes so far this morning have taken place in Italy, where students have clashed with riot police. Italy’s CGIL union has organised 100 protest events on Wednesday in Italy to mark a four-hour general strike, but it is students who are attracting attention in cities across Italy. From Rome, Tom Kington reports: The windows of a bank in Milan were reportedly smashed by protesting students, while far right students in Rome threw stones at police in a bid to break through a barricade to reach Palazzo Chigi, the residence of prime minister Mario Monti, which sits next door to the Italian parliament, where a budget law is being voted today. Police in Brescia charged against students congregating at the town’s station. Susanna Camusso, the head of the CGIL is meanwhile heading a march which started from the gates of the troubled ThyssenKrupp steelworks in Terni in Umbria. In Turin, thousands of protesters marched behind a model dragon representing global finance, with a placard in its jaws on which the word “Work” was written. A raid on the city’s tax office was met with tear gas fired by police. In Milan, transport workers, train conductors and hospital employees joined the students in the streets. The strike follows a tense day on Tuesday for Italian government ministers. In Sardinia, industry minister Corrado Passera and Fabrizio Barca, minister for territorial cohesion, needed to be evacuated by helicopter from a meeting on the local economy after protesters lined a road with burning cars. In Naples, a talk given by labour minister Elsa Fornero was interrupted by a man who threatened to slash his wrists to protest his daughter’s inability to find work. Protesters clashed with police in the city on Monday. Here's a photo of the protests that are starting now in central Athens (see 10.54 for details) If you're taking part in a march today, or on strike, or simply feeling the impact of today's protests, we'd love to here from you. If you're on Twitter, please tweet your pics to @guardian with the hashtag #14N. Thanks! In Greece, the frontline of Europe's debt crisis, protesters are taking to the streets as public and private sector employees stage a three-hour work stoppage. Our Athens correspondent Helena Smith writes: While the Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras is upbeat, with the conservative leader announcing that he expects a total of €44.6bn in loans to be handed over by creditors in the coming weeks, unions representing ordinary Greeks predict that the worst is only just beginning for a nation on course to endure it sixth straight year of recession amid every worsening poverty and unemployment. "The price of this money is more misery for Greeks who are now undergoing their worst ever crisis in modern times." said Ilias Iliopoulos at the civil servants' union Adedy. "There will be more cuts in salaries and pensions not to mention firings in the public sector," he lamented. Greek unionists in both the public and private sector have staged some 19 general strikes this years alone - but with little effect. The pan-European action follows months of efforts to coordinate anti-austerity protests across the continent with trade unionists frequently visiting Athens in recent months. "We are a small country and so there is only so much that we can achieve," said Iliopoulos. "Greece is no longer alone. Other countries in Europe are suffering from these terrible neo-liberal policies. This is the best way of getting our message heard." There are now reports that 62 people have been arrested so far today in Spain, with 34 people injured (including 18 policemen). Reuters reports that there have been clashes in Madrid this morning: Spanish anti-riot police and protesters clashed on Wednesday in central Madrid during a general strike. Two protesters were arrested and police hit others with night-sticks. As I blogged at 8.05am, today's protests in Spain began before dawn. Here's another good photo from the centre of Madrid this morning. Pockets of demonstrators led by trade unions gathered across Germany this morning as a sign of solidarity towards colleagues elsewhere in Europe, our Berlin correspondent Kate Connolly reports. But apart from several cancelled flights to and from destinations hit by strikes elsewhere, Germany remains largely untouched by the unrest. Michael Sommer, head of DGB, one of Germany's largest trade unions which has organised several solidarity demonstrations across the country, called on politicians to take more heed of social imbalances as they sought ways to battle the crisis. Sommer said: The austerity policies are not working...It not only make no sense to try to tackle the crisis with cuts, it is also dangerous. Instead he said the crisis should be tackled with a "comprehensive growth and investment programme". He added that the European strikes sent a "strong signal: we cannot continue like this". Kate also reports that that Chancellor Angela Merkel – towards whom much of the strikers' rage is directed – said she welcomed the protests, saying everyone had a right to demonstrate. "I spent 34 years living in a country where you could not demonstrate," she said, referring to her East German origins. Just in: photos from the rail strike in Belgium today, which appears to have caused significant disruption (see 8.20am). Here, Belgian workers with flares demonstrate on rail tracks and block trains: Not everyone has had to wait in a chilly railway station, though: Trade unions are to hold 130 marches across France today in support of anti-austerity strikes in Europe. The unions, in a joint declaration, said they wanted to show “firm opposition to austerity measures which would plunge Europe into stagnation, if not recession” creating deep “injustices”. Our Paris correspondent, Angelique Chrisafis, reports: Francois Hollande, at his first official press conference last night, argued that the French demonstrations “were not questioning our politics, but rather supporting it.” The Socialist president, who was elected for his opposition to one-size-fits-all austerity across Europe yesterday admitted France's high public spending needed to be trimmed in these times of economic crisis. But in French political semantics, the word “austerity” remains taboo. And this morning, Jean-Marc Ayrault, the French prime minister denied any recourse to the dreaded a-word. He told French radio: A rigorous approach to get our public accounts under control, that's true. But austerity, you know what that means: cuts to salaries, pensions, family benefits, it means thousands of job cuts, that's not what we practise. Ayrault said the French state would make efforts to deal with its spending, and look closely at the social security system and local authorities, without detailing where these budget cuts would fall. Here's a view from Madrid via Andrew Moody, an Australian living in Spain. ATMs in Madrid vandalised, garbage uncollected, more traffic than normal, walked to work to avoid the metro The streets of Florence are now heaving with protesters (see also 9.24am) Britain's TUC will deliver a letter to the European Commission's London offices later today, urging European leaders to change their approach to the crisis. It warns that: The austerity measures that the European Commission, the IMF and the European Central Bank are imposing on some countries and advocating for others are dragging the whole of Europe into economic stagnation.... These measures, far from re-establishing confidence in the financial markets, only serve to worsen imbalances and foster injustice. Workers and citizens are paying the price for a crisis they did not cause, in unemployment, falling wages and living standards and cuts in public services.' European unemployment levels have been hitting record highs month after month. The latest data showed that 25.751 million men and women are without jobs across the EU, where the unemployment rate is 10.6%. In the eurozone, the rate is 11.6%, or 23.3% for young people. Jude Kirton-Darling of the European Trade Union Confederation has told the BBC that today's general strike was called to highlight the fact that austerity is actually making the crisis in Europe worse. Kirton-Darling said: It's increasing inequalities, it's increasing the social instability in society and it's not resolving the economic crisis. Latest word from Spain is that 131 flights have been cancelled (including those BA flights from London). And the railway platforms in Madrid were deserted this morning: People travelling by air from the UK have been hit by today's strike action, with British Airways cancelling eight round-trip flights between London and Madrid and Barcelona, and two return services to Lisbon. EasyJet has also cancelled flights. ITV News has more details: Strikes cause flight misery for UK travellers Over in Italy, protesters have gathered in Florence for an anti-austerity strike. Here are some photos from the scene: The photo above shows a near-empty arrival hall at Madrid Atocha rail station in Spain this morning. And one resident in Madrid reports that the situation is calm: Today is billed as the "1st Pan-European General Strike", with around 40 unions taking part across 23 countries. Only Spain and Portugal are actually holding full-blown 'general strikes', but there is significant action across the region. Here's some details: Spain: General strike all day. Major protest in the centre of Madrid tonight. Around 600 flights have been cancelled (according to Sky). And just 20% of train services are expected to run. Portugal General strike all day. Protests in 40 Portuguese towns and cities. Around 160 flights cancelled. Lisbon Metro is closed. Just 10% of train services are expected to run. Greece A three-hour stoppage from noon (10am GMT). Rallies in Athens from noon, ending in Syntagma Square. EasyJet has rescheduled 10 flights (more details on disruption in Greece here) Italy Workers will hold a four-hour stoppage. France No official strike, but demonstrations are taking place across the country. Belgium Rail workers are on strike, disrupting services (see 8.20am) UK Anti-austerity rally in Westminster tonight. If you have more details - please let me know at graeme.wearden@guardian.co.uk or @graemewearden. The Spanish government says 32 people have been arrested at this morning's protests (see 8.05am for details and photos), with 15 injured. That's via Associated Press, which adds: The General Workers Union said the nationwide stoppage, the second this year, was being heeded by nearly 100 percent of workers Wednesday in the automobile, energy, shipbuilding and constructions industries. Spain is at the forefront of the eurozone crisis, with one in four people out of work. Its economy has been shrinking for the last year, and is expected to contract by another 1.5% in 2013. Today's strike action has disrupted rail travel in Belgium. Via Twitter, Fiona Wilson tells me that she's been unable to catch a train from Brussels to Switzerland - and it appears other services are also hit. Belgium's rail network warns that services could be disrupted through the day. Simon Nixon of the Wall Street Journal reports that Madrid Airport isn't running quite as well as he'd like... There have already been clashes between police and protesters in Madrid this morning, as Spain's general strike got underway. Demonstrators tried to stop buses leaving the main Madrid bus station, where mounted officers had been deployed. A picketer was also arrested by riot police officers, apparently after trying to close a pub with others picketers at the start of the general strike. And in Malaga, other picketers clashed with riot police officers as they tried to stop a truck leaving the city's main food warehouse "MercaMalaga". The European Trade Union Confederation released this video clip urging workers to take part in today's action, to put pressure on politicans to prioritise growth and employment: We cannot afford to wait any longer - the policies that have carried out until now have failed. We must take another course. If you're a Twitter user, you can follow the day's developments using the hashtags #14N and #14Nov2012. For example: The European Day of Action and Solidarity is organised by the European Trade Union Confederation (ETUC), with the slogan: "For Jobs and Solidarity in Europe. No to Austerity. ETUC has issued a declaration in which it warns that austerity is: ...dragging Europe into economic stagnation, indeed recession, as well as the continuing dismantling of the European social model. These measures, far from reestablishing confidence, only serve to worsen imbalances and foster injustice. ETUC's website also contains a Google map showing all the protests taking place across Europe today. European workers are holding their biggest ever co-ordinated strike action and protests today against the austerity programmes that are gripping the region. General strikes are already underway in Spain and Portugal, and workers in Greece and Italy are also expected to walk out. The European Day of Action and Solidarity is designed as a sign to leaders to abandon the programmes of tax rises and spending cuts that are being implemented since the financial crisis began. The disruption is expected to cripple transport links and government services, such as schools. Unions in other European countries may also join the action. We'll be tracking the protests across Europe throughout the day, as well as other key events in the financial crisis today as usual.
fields.headline: Europe's day of anti-austerity strikes and protests turn violent - as it happened
fields.trailText: Riot police have clashed with protesters in Spain, Italy and Portugal as European unions hold a Day of Action against austerity

webTitle: FTSE falters as Spanish bailout hopes fade and economic data disappoints, but Amec pleases investors

fields.standfirst: Investors turn cautious again as eurozone woes continue amid strike action across the continent
fields.body:
A litany of bad economic news sent leading shares lower once more, but engineering group Amec bucked the trend after a positive update.

The company, which recently announced executive changes and a restructuring, said trading was in line with expectations after a strong performance in the oil and gas sector. Seymour Pierce analyst Kevin Lapwood said:

Despite the recent senior management departures and profits warnings among the peer group (Cape), which have been received nervously and adversely affected the share price, the Amec statement was in-line with expectations and underpins our 2012 estimates. The order book was down slightly at £3.6bn from the last update in June but well ahead of the £3.3bn reported this time last year.
The shares have underperformed the market by 6% in the last three months and now trade at a discount to the oil service peers. We reiterate our buy stance and target price of £12.50.

Amec added 23p to £10.56, making it one of the biggest risers in the leading index. Also on the way up was pumps maker Weir, 9p better at £17.47. It benefited from Amec's positivity on the oil and gas sector, and also from news that Nomura had moved from reduce to neutral and raised its price target on Weir from £14 to £18.50.

Elsewhere Prudential put on 5.5p to 871p following a positive third quarter update, which showed a better than expected 13% rise in profits, thanks to continuing strong growth in Asia.

And Centrica made a successful late burst for the top spot in the FTSE 100 after it said it had found nothing unusual in wholesale gas trades on 28 September, part of reports that a number of major energy companies had allegedly fixed prices.

But overall it was another dismal day for investors. The Bank of England cut its growth forecasts, protests against austerity disrupted much of Europe and US retail sales fell 0.3% in October after three consecutive monthly rises (although Hurricane Sandy was blamed for some of the decline.)

On top of that, EU commissioner Olli Rehn dashed expectations of an early Spanish bailout, something which had lifted the markets on Tuesday.

So the FTSE 100 finished 64.24 points at 5722.01. Miners were among the main losers as metal prices fell on worries about global demand. Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation fell 13.4p to 276.2p and Kazakhmys closed 22p lower at 661p.

Evraz, the Russian steel producer controlled by Chelsea owner Roman Abramovich, lost 16.4p to 217.4p on news it wants an amendment to covenants associated with a $750m bond maturing in 2015. It said:

[Evraz] is seeking approval...of the holders of the notes to remove a covenant requiring the company to maintain the net leverage ratio at or below a specified level.

A number of companies saw their shares fall after going ex-dividend, including Marks & Spencer, down 6.8p at 378.4p, GlaxoSmithKline, 30.5p lower at 1326p, and Royal Dutch Shell, whose B shares have fallen 62.5p to £21.64.

ITV edged up 0.1p to 94.7p as it continued to benefit from its well received trading statement. Alex DeGroote at Panmure Gordon said:

Some short closing may in part explain the market's strong reaction to the third quarter update. However, earlier this year, we laid out the case for sustained share price upside at ITV. Since then, profits have remained in an upgrade cycle, the dividend has been restored and the balance sheet has only got stronger. We maintain that ITV has a rare mix of operating leverage, asset backing and significant financial headroom, with a world-class management team.

Lower down the market, Finland's Talvivaara Mining Company, hit hard by a water leak which has stopped production at a nickel mine in the east of the country, recovered 21.6p to 105p. It said the leakage, which started more than a week ago, had now stopped but it would have to reassess its production targets once it was given permission to reopen the plant. Analysts are concerned the company may need a rights issue.

But TalkTalk Telecom dropped 11p to 210p after hitting an all time high on Tuesday in the wake of a positive trading update.

Icap, the interdealer broker, fell more than 9%, losing 28.5p to 281.4p after its profits fell due to poor market conditions and it saw no sign of an imminent pick-up in trading.

Darty dropped 2.75p to 43p after the company - now a Europe-focused retailer following the disposal of the now collapsed UK group Comet - revealed a slowdown in sales. In a sell note Philip Dorgan at Panmure Gordon said:

Sales in the second quarter are worse than the first and, while comparatives ease in the second half, we are not confident. We are therefore reducing our target price from 50p to 40p and retaining our sell recommendation.

Finally, set-top box maker Pace has seen its share price rise by around 20% in less than a month, so a positive trading update was an excuse for some profit taking.

The company said 2012 revenues were expected to be flat on the 2011 figures, with no impact in the second half from a serious disruption in the supply of hard disk drives after floods in Thailand. Previously Pace had expected a $4m impact on earnings in the final six months of the year.

It closed 10.3p lower at 184.7p.

webTitle: Black Friday slips into 'Grey Thursday' as retail giants face staff backlash

fields.standfirst: Workers criticise 'pure greed' as stores like Walmart and Target encroach on family time by opening on Thanksgiving Day
fields.body:
Jackie Goebel has worked for Walmart for 24 years, but this year, for the first time, she will spend the Thanksgiving holiday working at the retail giant. Like many of her colleagues, she is not happy. "Walmart has become a company so obsessed by the bottom line and greed that it no longer values the importance of the people and families that work for it," she said.

For decades, Thanksgiving has been sacrosanct for Americans – a non-denominational national celebration, and a guaranteed family holiday for most big companies. For retailers, it's also the day before Black Friday, the shopping bacchanal that marks the start of the holiday season.

Now Black Friday is slipping into "Grey Thursday" and taking retail workers with it. Walmart will open its doors at 8pm on Thanksgiving Day. Others, including Sears, Toys R Us and Kmart, will also open at 8pm on Thanksgiving. Target opens at 9pm. Gap is planning to open 1,100 of its stores. Retail experts predict that if this year proves a hit, stores will open earlier next year.

Goebel, 61, lost her daughter to cancer in 2007. She, too, worked at Walmart. This year Goebel was planning to spend the holiday with her husband and her granddaughter. "An experience like that makes you realise what's important," said Goebel.

Sam Walton, Walmart's hard-driven founder, once visited the store in Kenosha, Wisconsin, where Goebel works. She believes he would have been horrified by what has become of his company. "He was a hell of a businessman, but he had respect for the people who worked for him," she said. "To me, this is pure greed."

Walmart workers are planning strike action over the Thanksgiving holiday, supported by the United Food and Commercial Workers (UFCW) and OUR Walmart, an associate led group that in October helped organise the first strike at the retailer in its 70-year history.

A Walmart spokesman said "a very small number of associates" were raising concerns. "While the opinions expressed by this group don't represent the views of the vast majority of the more than 1.3 million Walmart associates in the US, when our associates bring forward concerns, we listen. Associates have direct lines of communication with their management team and we work to understand their concerns," he said.

"Last year, our highest customer traffic during the Black Friday weekend was during the 10pm hour on Thursday. According to the National Retail Federation, Thanksgiving night shopping has surged over the past three years. Most of our stores are open 24 hours and, historically, much of our Black Friday preparations have been done on Thanksgiving, which is not unusual in the retail industry."

Walmart is not the only retailer facing a backlash from staff. Casey St Clair, 24, was so incensed by Target's decision to cancel Thanksgiving for her and her colleagues that she set up a petition on Change.org, lobbying the retailer's CEO for action. It now has over 200,000 signatures.

"Every year the opening gets earlier and earlier. Before long, we will be open all day on Thanksgiving," she said. "Thanksgiving is a day about families, and giving thanks for what we have got. There are a lot of single parents at Target. This just ruins the holiday for them."

She said she had been surprised by management's attitude to the holiday. "I have always enjoyed working here and they have always seemed flexible," she said. But not about this. "Their attitude seems to be: if you don't turn up for work, you don't have a job."

A spokeswoman for Target said:

Target's opening time was carefully evaluated with our guests, team and the business in mind. Across the country, team member preferences were considered in creating our store staffing schedules. Thanksgiving weekend is one of the busiest of the year, and we appreciate our Target team's flexibility on this weekend and throughout the holiday season.

It's not hard to see why retailers are prepared to make their staff so unhappy. Last year, about 28.7 million people did their Black Friday shopping on Thanksgiving Day, according to the National Retail Federation, up from 22 million in 2010. The number is still less than a third of the roughly 86 million shoppers who took to stores on Black Friday itself, but it's growing, and likely to continue the trend this year.

Dan de Grandpre, CEO of Dealnews.com, a shopping deals tracking service, said Grey Thursday was here to stay. "Last year, Target and Walmart did it, and they were very successful. Stores that sat it out like JC Penney, for example, suffered," he said.

Retailers are aiming to capture as much of the money that shoppers have set aside for shopping as early as possible, said Grandpre. If the competition isn't open, they are potentially losing out.

"It's very tough for employees and it's a big decision to make, but if the consumers are willing to shop, the stores are willing to do it," said Grandpre. If stores benefit again this year, he expects even earlier opening times next year.

But Grandpre said that Dealnews's research showed 70% of the deals were available online, and that anyone expecting to avoid lines by arriving on Thanksgiving is likely to be disappointed. "Realistically, if the shop opens at 8pm on Thanksgiving, you are going to have to be there several hours earlier to make sure of getting the best deals," he said. With so many deals available online, Grandpre says he finds it hard to see the point.

Goebel, too, believes customers will eventually push back against Thanksgiving opening. "I truly believe that people would rather be spending the day with their families than spending it in line," she said.

webTitle: FTSE 100 fall accelerates after Wall Street opening and Rehn comments on Spain

fields.standfirst: EU commissioner says Spain unlikely to request bailout in near term but 2014 measures not enough
fields.body:
Leading UK shares are continuing their decline after an opening fall on Wall Street amid continuing fears about the US fiscal cliff and the eurozone debt crisis.

Markets were buoyed late on Tuesday by talk that Spain, finally, would bite the bullet and request a bailout. But EU economic and monetary affairs commissioner Olli Rehn has seemingly punctured that balloon.

He has said Spain has taken effective debt reduction measures for 2012 and 2013, and was on the right track. Nor was it likely to request a bailout in the near term.

But 2014 was a different matter, he added, with its measures for that year falling short of what was required by ministers.

The market has reacted badly to that point. With Wall Street down 60 points, the FTSE 100 was already under pressure, but Rehn's comments have helped push it 58.09 points lower to 5728.16. Bond yields in Spain have edged higher, moving closer to 6%.

webTitle: Financial markets going through worst period in decades, says ICAP boss

fields.standfirst: Michael Spencer warns trading volumes may never recover to pre-financial crisis levels as ICAP reports 26% pre-tax profits fall
fields.body:
Michael Spencer, the chief executive of interdealer broker ICAP and former Tory party treasurer, has warned that financial markets are suffering the worst crisis he has seen in his 36 years in the City.

As he reported a 26% fall in ICAP's pre-tax profits in the first half of the year, Spencer said trading volumes had fallen across all asset classes all around the world and may never recover to levels seen before the financial crisis.

"The past six months have certainly been one of the toughest periods in my 36 years in the City," he said on Wednesday. "There is a pessimistic view that bank trading is not going to recover to where it was in the past. I'm not saying that's impossible."

Spencer said the eurozone crisis had "punctured confidence" in the banking industry and made banks much more conservative traders.

ICAP warned investors ICAP's poor performance so far this year would drag its full-year profits towards the "low end" of analysts expectations of £300m-£332m.

Pre-tax profits in the six months to the end of September fell 26% to £137m, while revenues slid 14% to £746m.

Spencer said the poor results would be reflected in smaller bonuses paid to staff – including himself. "Bonuses for the majority of people in the firm, including me, will be lower, he said, indicated that bonuses would fall at a greater rate than the slide in revenues by stating a 14% fall in the average bonus would be a "conservative" estimate. Spencer took home £5.5m in pay and bonuses last year.

ICAP's shares dropped 10% to 280.5p – the biggest one day fall in more than two years.

webTitle: Pace shares fall nearly 5% on profit taking following positive update

fields.standfirst: Set-top box maker reports lower than expected costs from Thai flood disruption
fields.body:
Set-top box maker Pace has seen its share price rise by around 20% in less than a month, so a positive trading update has been an excuse for some profit taking.

The company said 2012 revenues were expected to be flat on the 2011 figures, with no impact in the second half from a serious disruption in the supply of hard disk drives after floods in Thailand. Previously Pace had expected a $4m impact on earnings in the final six months of the year.

Net debt will fall faster than forecast to $200m by the year end, and it has seen strong demand for its media server products from Comcast and DirecdTV in the US.

But after the recent rise, its shares have dropped 9.2p to 185.8p. Analysts are still positive, however. Alex Jarvis at Peel Hunt kept her buy recommendation and raised her target price from 200P to 250p:

2012 revenues should be 1% ahead of our forecast and EBITA/earnings per share 3% ahead, helped by lower hard disc drive costs. Free cash flow generation is significantly ahead of guidance earlier in the year, at around $160m. The combination of an attractive free cash flow yield of around 16% and the prospect of a debt-free balance sheet in the first half of 2014 support our raised target price.

Jonathan Imlah at Canaccord Genuity said:

We are encouraged not only by the ongoing cost reductions at Pace but particularly by the effective measures taken to improve cash generation and to transform the supply chain, which should have long-lasting implications.
The continued rise in the share price diminishes the chances of the much-talked-about combination of Pace and Motorola. That said, we expect further progress on both costs and cash generation over the next few months. This in turn should feed through into a higher rating.

webTitle: UK economy faces long and winding road to recovery, warns Mervyn King | Larry Elliott

fields.bodyText: For once Sir Mervyn King struggled to find an appropriate sporting metaphor to sum up the current state of the economy when presenting the Bank of England's inflation report. Instead, he revealed a hitherto hidden knowledge of the Beatles to describe where the UK was heading. Sadly, the governor did not choose one of the Fab Four's cheerier numbers – Getting Better or Here Comes the Sun – but said there was a long and winding road to recovery. King was in gloomy mood. He doesn't expect the pickup in activity in the third quarter of 2012 to last and thinks there is a chance output will fall in the current quarter. Growth will remain below its historic trend for the next two years and the level of national output in late 2014 will still be below where it was before the recession started in early 2008. It was more Leonard Cohen than Paul McCartney. The outlook for the UK is for a mild dose of stagflation. Growth will be weaker than previously forecast while inflation will be higher, continuing to breach its 2% target for the next 12 months. As usual, King strongly insisted it would be a mistake for the Bank to tighten monetary policy to hit the inflation target – either by raising interest rates or by withdrawing some of the £375bn in quantitative easing – since to do so would lead to rising unemployment and slower growth. It was not the Bank's fault that inflation continued to misbehave. The cost of living was elevated because of factors beyond Threadneedle Street's control – such as dearer global food and energy prices and, more recently, the trebling of university tuition fees. Meanwhile, Britain's recovery hopes were being thwarted by an unfavourable global environment that made it tough going for exporters. Missing the inflation target has had consequences, however. The fact that wages have been growing less rapidly than prices – illustrated again by Wednesday's average earnings figures – means real incomes have been squeezed. At a time when pay settlements are low, and are likely to remain low, a rise in inflation slows growth by reducing consumer spending power and increasing business costs. This suggests the Bank might eventually need to consider fresh attempts to stimulate activity. King's comments that "there are limits to the ability of domestic policy to stimulate private sector demand" could be seen as an example that the monetary policy committee has been listening to the Beatles' Let it Be. That, though, was not what the governor meant. The MPC retains its faith in asset purchases (QE) and had not ruled out further moves. Hardly unexpectedly, King sought to downplay the significance of George Osborne grabbing the cash surplus sitting in the Asset Purchase Facility. This will mean the government has to borrow £37bn less in the next financial year and the governor insisted this did not impair the Bank's independence. What it certainly does imply is a £37bn loosening of monetary policy – QE by the back door – which the MPC seems happy enough to endorse. The other way to loosen monetary policy is through a lower exchange rate and King blatantly tried to talk down the value of sterling by making it clear that he is unhappy about the 8% appreciation in the pound over the past year. Given time, King thinks the economy can make a fully recovery. But not immediately and only after a Hard Day's Night.

The UK economy risks suffering from a triple-dip recession amid a period of persistently low growth that will last until the next election, the governor of the Bank of England has warned.

Sir Mervyn King cut Britain's growth forecast to 1% next year and warned that output was more likely than not to remain below pre-crisis levels over the next three years. "There seems a greater risk that the UK economy may be in a period of persistent low growth," he said on Wednesday.

The UK economy emerged from a double-dip recession in the third quarter of this year, when the economy grew by 1%, but King warned that this was driven by one-off factors. "Continuing the recent zig-zag pattern, output growth is likely to fall back sharply in the fourth quarter as the boost from the Olympics in the summer is reversed – indeed output may shrink a little this quarter," he said. If that period of contraction continues into 2013, the UK could drop into a triple-dip recession.

At the same time, the Bank significantly raised its inflation forecasts. Inflation is now is expected to reach around 3% in the near-term and not fall back significantly until the second half of 2013, later than previously thought.

UK inflation jumped to a surprise five-month high of 2.7% last month, driven by rises in tuition fees and dearer food bills. Energy price rises over the next few months are likely to drive it even higher.

King said the outlook for inflation was the main reason why the monetary policy committee decided not to expand the quantitative easing (QE) programme in November. He said there were limits to what monetary policy could do to boost an economy undergoing far-reaching adjustments in the wake of the financial crisis and amid severe headwinds from the eurozone debt crisis.

But economists said the bank may still engage in more QE in the future. Howard Archer of IHS Global Insight said: "With economic recovery currently looking feeble, fragile and far from guaranteed, we believe that the Bank of England will ultimately decide to give the economy a further helping hand with a final £50bn of QE. This seems most likely to occur in the first quarter of 2013."

Labour said this gloomy outlook proved the coalition government's economic plans were not working. The shadow chancellor, Ed Balls, said: "This sobering report shows why David Cameron and George Osborne's deeply complacent approach to the economy is so misplaced. Their failing policies have seen two years of almost no growth and the Bank of England is now forecasting lower growth and higher inflation than just a few months ago."

webTitle: Morrisons disloyalty card risks upsetting regular shoppers | Nils Pratley

fields.bodyText: Unlike Tesco and Sainsbury's, Morrisons does not operate a loyalty card. It does, however, now have a disloyalty card. The chain is trying to woo rivals' customers with 10%-off discount cards. It's an invitation-only "local" tactic, Morrisons emphasises, and the maximum saving is capped at £100 (on £1,000 worth of shopping) until the end of this year. So far, 5,000 people have registered for the cards. An eye-catching promotion, certainly. And, after reporting Morrisons' weakest like-for-like quarterly sales numbers for years, you can understand why chief executive Dalton Philips might feel he has to try something different. The trouble is, the tactic risks annoying Morrisons' loyal shoppers. Many, one suspects, will feel that if anyone deserves a 10% saving it's them. It's irritating to think the shopper in the next aisle is bagging a Christmas lunch at a better price just because he or she normally shops at Asda. That's marketing, Morrisons' marketing department might feel. Yes, but loyal shoppers' revenge will be fascinating to watch. In the age of social media, Philip Dorgan, Panmure Gordon's analyst, predicts the law of unintended consequences will operate. He says: "We can see why this offer might make sense to the marketing geniuses. However, back in the real world, we think that offering non-Morrisons shoppers discounts, while giving your core shoppers nothing, makes no sense and can only make matters worse. In a viral world, a company cannot quietly go about its business. Customers find out, and quickly." That sounds spot-on.

webTitle: Amec boosted by oil and gas business, while Evraz falls on bond amendment

fields.standfirst: Engineer Amec pleases City with update, with pump maker Weir benefiting from positive news on energy sector
fields.body:
A strong performance in the oil and gas market has lifted engineering group Amec.

The company, which recently announced executive changes and a restructuring, said trading was in line with expectations and its order book remained strong at £3.6bn. Chief executive Samir Brikho said:

Amec continues to make good progress in 2012, reflecting in particular a strong performance in the conventional oil and gas sector. Demand for our services and investment in our end markets remain good, despite the on-going economic uncertainty.
We are on track to deliver double-digit underlying revenue growth for the full year and we expect to deliver good growth in 2013.

The update has lifted Amec to the top of the FTSE 100, with its shares up 29p to £10.62, and analysts were generally positive. Bank of America Merrill Lynch said:

Amec's statement brings home a very solid message, showing that despite the introduction of the new business units to be in place from next year, and some management changes, activity continues to be strong, and execution remains sound. There is not much new to note in the statement; however, this in itself is a positive, in our view, given some of the challenges other companies in the sector have faced. For Amec, having a consistent level of operational performance is encouraging and the outlook, which is relatively unchanged, shows promise.

At Seymour Pierce, Kevin Lapwood had a similar theme:

Despite the recent senior management departures and profits warnings among the peer group (Cape), which have been received nervously and adversely affected the share price, the Amec statement was in-line with expectations and underpins our 2012 estimates. The order book was down slightly at £3.6bn from the last update in June but well ahead of the £3.3bn reported this time last year.
Amec is currently £300m into a £400m share buyback programme, and it strongly indicated that more returns of cash were likely next year. It does not need to run with cash balances and can comfortably cover acquisitions from existing balance sheet resources. The shares have underperformed the market by 6% in the last three months and now trade at a discount to the oil service peers. We reiterate our buy stance and target price of £12.50.

Investec's Keith Morris also has a buy recommendation but added:

Other than current trading, we are more concerned about the recent high profile senior management departures which are supposed to be linked to the change to a regional as opposed to a divisional reporting structure, but seem to us to possibly imply friction over strategy within the board.

Close behind Amec in the FTSE 100 risers is pumps maker Weir, up 31p at £17.69. It benefited from Amec's positivity on the oil and gas sector, and also from news that Nomura had moved from reduce to neutral and raised its price target on Weir from £14 to £18.50. The bank said:

We have benchmarked [Weir's] oil and gas division against 17 other industrial end markets and show that the current profitability of the business is abnormally high. We attribute this to the immaturity of the end market and highlight that (1) low OEM capacity utilisation and (2) increasing aftermarket captivity could lead to O&G equipment margins to decline from 21% to 10% on recovery. This would take the division's margins to 19%-20%, 450 basis points below current 24%. In the worst case this would pose 8.5% earnings per share downside risk in 2014, but we think a gradual impact is more likely.
We upgrade to a neutral rating as pricing headwinds are less imminent than we had earlier anticipated and as near-term earnings per share downgrade risk is now more limited.

Elsewhere Prudential has put on 4p to 869.5p following a positive third quarter update, which showed a better than expected 13% rise in profits, thanks to continuing strong growth in Asia.

But Evraz, the Russian steel producer controlled by Chelsea owner Roman Abramovich, has fallen 8p to 225.8p on news it wants an amendment to covenants associated with a $750m bond maturing in 2015. It said:

[Evraz] is seeking approval...of the holders of the notes to remove a covenant requiring the company to maintain the net leverage ratio at or below a specified level.

A number of companies saw their shares go ex-dividend, including Marks & Spencer, down 6p at 379.2p, GlaxoSmithKline, 19p lower at 1337.5p, and Royal Dutch Shell, whose B shares have fallen 37.5p to £21.89.

webTitle: Biggest rise in unemployment claims for a year as Olympics effect fades

fields.bodyText: The number of people claiming the dole rose at its fastest rate in over a year last month as the jobs boost from the Olympics faded. But the unemployment rate, which tracks the number of people looking for work, dropped to 7.8% in the three months to September helped by a fall in youth unemployment. The most timely measure of employment – the claimant count, which tracks the number of people receiving jobseeker's allowance – rose by 10,100 last month, the largest increase since September 2011. Analysts were expecting the figures to be unchanged from the previous month. Looking back to the third quarter, the wider measure of people looking for work fell by 49,000, to 2.5 million. Youth unemployment, which the coalition government has sought to tackle through Nick Clegg's youth contract, eased 0.8% but remained high at almost 21% for the three months to September. The coalition government highlighted these bright spots in the Office for National Statistics' jobs report. The employment minister, Mark Hoban, said: "It's good news to see yet another increase in the number of people in work and to see unemployment fall again. The fall in youth unemployment is particularly welcome, although we're not complacent about the scale of the challenge still facing us." But unions said the figures showed austerity was not working. Paul Kenny, the GMB general secretary, said: "With unemployment stuck at two and a half million, a lot of families face a miserable Christmas without any hope of getting a job. It is definitely hurting, but it's not working." Despite the mixed picture, economists said the data showed the job market was deteriorating. Although employment rose by 100,000 in the three months to September, that was below expectations of 135,000, and considerably lower than a rise of 212,000 in August Martin Beck at Capital Economics said: "[These] figures on the UK labour market suggest that its recent resilience is finally starting to fade. The pace of expansion in employment is slowing. And the figures may still be benefiting from Olympics-related hiring in July and August. Indeed, the claimant count measure of unemployment rose in September, which suggests that the labour market may be beginning to weaken as the Olympics effect fades." Meanwhile, the squeeze on household budgets continues. Average incomes rose at an annual rate of 1.8% from the third quarter last year, almost one percentage point below inflation, meaning spending power is falling. Figures released on Tuesday showed inflation rose to 2.7%, driven by university tuition fees and dearer food bills.

webTitle: Britvic and Irn-Bru maker AG Barr agree £1.4bn merger

fields.bodyText: The companies behind Robinsons squash and Irn-Bru have agreed to a £1.4bn merger, creating one of the biggest soft drinks firms in Europe. The merger of Britvic and its Scottish rival AG Barr to create the snappily named Barr Britvic Soft Drinks will bring Robinsons Barley Water, J2O and Fruit Shoot under the same roof as Irn-Bru, Tizer and Rubicon in a group with annual sales of more than £1.5bn. However, Roger White, the current chief executive of AG Barr, who will lead the combined firm, warned that the merger will lead to 350-500 job cuts as the business strives to achieve annual savings of £35m. He said it was too early to say exactly how many jobs would be lost and whether Britvic or AG Barr employees would be most heavily affected, but he added that the "commercial logic" of putting the two business together was "enormous". Gerald Corbett, chairman of Britvic, who will continue in the same role at the combined company, said the merger, which is subject to shareholder approval, would "create a world-class soft drinks company … AG Barr and Britvic are a fantastic fit with complementary strengths and we will benefit from very significant synergies". Britvic shareholders will own 63% of the new company, with AG Barr holding the rest. Paul Moody, Britvic's chief executive, who presided over the £25m recall of Fruit Shoot drinks as a result of faulty bottle caps, will not have a role in the new company. Barr Britvic will be based at AG Barr's current headquarters in Cumbernauld, North Lanarkshire. AG Barr Barr Soft Drinks was started in 1875 in Falkirk. Iron Brew – as it was then spelled – was launched in 1901. The Irn-Bru recipe is known by only three people in the world – former chairman Robin Barr, his daughter and company secretary, Julie Barr, and one other AG Barr board director whose identity remains confidential. The spelling Irn-Bru was introduced in 1947 following concern over proposed changes to food labelling regulations. AG Barr employs about 980 staff across 11 UK sites. As well as Irn-Bru, the company owns the Tizer, Barr's Originals, Orangina and Rubicon brands. Britvic The company traces its origins to a chemist in Chelmsford, Essex, in the mid-19th century. In 1949 a range of juices were launched under the name British Vitamin Products. In 1971 the British Vitamin Product Company changed its name to Britvic. It acquired the UK licence for Dr Pepper in 1982 and Tango in 1986. In 1995 it bought Robinsons from Reckitt & Colman. Britvic floated on the London Stock Exchange in 2005. The company's head office is in Hertfordshire. It employs around 3,300 staff and sells 1.9bn litres of drinks each year.

webTitle: Icap drops 6% as chief executive Michael Spencer bemoans one of worst periods in 36 years

fields.standfirst: Interdealer broker reports 26% slump in half year profits and sees no imminent improvement
fields.body:
Michael Spencer, the chief executive of interdealer broker Icap and former Tory party treasurer, believes the current market conditions are among the worst he has seen in his 36 years in the City.

Reporting a 26% slump in half year profits, he said trading volumes had fallen everywhere - in equities, futures, foreign exchange, commodities, fixed income and over the counter trading. He said:

This has been caused by a combination of factors: global economic weakness, the continuing eurozone crisis, bank recapitalisation and deleveraging, uncertainty over regulatory reform, quantitative easing and near zero rates, to name the main ones.
I do not believe this negative environment will continue indefinitely but equally I do not expect it to improve imminently. It has been a time to weather a hard storm.

Since the year end, trading conditions have remained challenging, with a literal "hard storm" in the form of hurricane Sandy shutting the US markets and causing widespread disruption. The fourth quarter is usually the strongest one for the company but it does not expect a major improvement compared to the final three months of last year. It said full year profits would be at the lower end of City forecasts of £300m to £332m.

The gloomy news has sent Icap's shares down 6%, an 18.8p drop to 291.7p. Analyst Gary Greenwood at Shore Capital said:

We would expect the shares to struggle in the short-term given the weak outlook and further earnings downgrade risk.

James Hamilton at Numis said:

Icap are guiding to the bottom of the £300m-£332m underlying pre-tax profit forecast range for the full year. This clearly assumes a substantial recovery in the fourth quarter as guided to this time last year and that did not materialise. Numbers are expected to fall significantly and we expect to (yet again) cut our £312m forecast by 4%-6%. News flow is expected to remain poor. There is no reason to own the share today.

With the general strike across much of Europe, continuing worries about Greece and Spain, as well as the US fiscal cliff, the mood is not particularly upbeat so far. The FTSE 100 has fallen 27.24 points to 5759.01 but the FTSE 250 has fared better, down just 3.04 points at 11794.18.

Finland's Talvivaara Mining Company, hit hard by a water leak which has stopped production at a nickel mine in the east of the country, has recovered 16.6p to 100p. It said the leakage, which started more than a week ago, has now stopped but it will have to reassess its production targets once it is given permission to reopen the plant. Analysts are concerned the company may need a rights issue.

But TalkTalk Telecom has dropped 11.6p to 209.4p after hitting an all time high on Tuesday in the wake of a positive trading update.

The FTSE 100 has fallen 27.24 points to 5759.01 but the FTSE 250 has fared better, down just 3.04 points at 11794.18. Finland's Talvivaara Mining Company, hit hard by a water leak which has stopped production at a nickel mine in the east of the country, has recovered 16.6p to 100p. webTitle: Energy price manipulation 'could account for at least 50% of bill rises'

fields.standfirst: Five of the big six companies have raised bills recently, all blaming their actions in part on the current wholesale price
fields.body:
Update: On 7 November 2013 Ofgem and FCA concluded their investigation and found that there had been no market manipulation on 28 September 2012: http://www.fca.org.uk/news/statements/statement-gas-market-manipulation

Five of the big six energy companies have raised their gas and electricity prices in the last two months, with British Gas, SSE, Scottish Power, npower and EDF all blaming the current wholesale price as one of the reasons for raising household bills.

Since whistleblower Seth Freedman's allegations that the wholesale price has been manipulated, energy price comparison experts believe this could have an impact on the amount consumers and businesses pay for their power supply.

Joe Malinowski, founder of consumer price comparison site TheEnergyShop.com, who also worked as an energy analyst, explained that more than 50% of the cost an individual's bill is directly related to the wholesale price.

He said: "Energy suppliers have announced price increases this winter [and] all blamed wholesale energy market prices at least in part for the increase. So if the energy suppliers are saying it, then it must be true. Right?"

The date – 28 September – when the manipulation is alleged to have taken place, is also a key part of the story.

It is noteworthy because it was the last Friday before several major contracts with the big energy companies would come to an end. Therefore, if the price was artificially pushed down, the natural reaction would be that they would then rise again – giving the energy companies justification to claim that wholesale prices have risen.

James Constant, chairman of the price comparison website for businesses, EnergyForecaster.co.uk, explained: "It is interesting but by no means conclusive that in the immediate aftermath of the controversial date of 28 September we saw a drop in the gas price of some 2% and the month that followed saw an increase of 6%.

"October is also a particularly busy month for the business energy market, as it is one of the most common dates for contracts to be up for renewal. Someone has clearly benefited, but it's equally clear that the average British business most certainly has not."

With energy companies relying so heavily on the wholesale gas price movement for raising household bills, even companies such as Centrica, which produce their own gas from the North Sea, can benefit.

Malinowski explained: "British Gas buys a significant proportion of its gas from its own gas fields, but needs to set the transfer price of those purchases with reference to wholesale market benchmark prices."

In other words, regardless of whether a company produces its own gas, it relies on the prices set by the traders alleged to have fixed the price.

"The domestic energy market is more insulated against individual price movements, due to the hedging strategies," said Constant.

However, the benchmark figures on which the claims of manipulation are centred will still play a part in the energy companies' decision to increase their bills. For businesses and publicly-run institutions such as hospitals and schools, the impact from manipulation could be far greater.

Constant explained: "The business energy market is very much exposed to even small fluctuations in price and if the resultant market price was affected then thousands of businesses re-contracting in October will have been detrimentally affected."

• This article was amended on 14 November 2012 to remove E.ON from the list of energy companies that have raised gas and electricity prices in the past two months, and to include SSE.

webTitle: Quotas for women on boards best way to raise talent

fields.bodyText: Mandatory quotas for women on the boards of companies would be a dreadful idea. So says Maria Miller, the minister for women, who wants promotion to be based on removing barriers rather than political correctness. Britain, she notes in a speech on Wednesday, doesn't need a meddling Brussels to tell us how to run our businesses because the fact that 44% of all board appointments in the past six months have been women shows that the voluntary approach is working. That's one view. Another way of slicing and dicing the figures shows that not one woman executive director has been appointed in the past six months, with the real power wielded by men, as it always has been. But it is not the selective interpretation of the statistics that is the strongest counter to Miller's argument. Nor is it that the same voluntarist line is trotted out to no effect when it comes to executive pay. It is not even that Miller is missing the point when she describes quotas as patronising, when the real issue is women being passed over in favour of less talented men. No, the real problem with the voluntarist approach is that it will perpetuate mediocrity. Male boards will beget male boards, with the odd female director of human resources for those companies that like to consider themselves go-ahead. There would be a case for the status quo if the country was booming as a result of macho UK plc. But it isn't.
